pageData.text: The mammalian brain is a highly complex organ that occupies the <button class='glossary-text'>cranial</button> cavity and plays a central role in regulating the body’s response to change in the internal and external environment. Whereas there are some differences in the size of the structures and regions of brains from different mammalian species, the general structures and their relative locations are the same or very similar in a human brain. In this investigation, the student will dissect and closely examine an adult sheep brain, and relate the structures observed to their functions.

Preparation - 10 minutes
Activity 1: Dissection of the Mammalian Brain - 30 minutes

text: Paper towels
70% isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) or other non-bleach disinfectant
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking digital photos
Timer or stopwatch
Opaque trash bag

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Identify the major regions of the brain and associate them with their basic functions.
Identify surface features of each region of the brain.
Apply anatomical terminology while performing a midsagittal dissection of an adult mammalian brain.
Identify the major internal features of the cerebrum, diencephalon, <button class='glossary-text'>midbrain</button>, brainstem, and <button class='glossary-text'>cerebellum</button>.

pageData.text: Every year new discoveries are made about how the brain and the rest of the body communicate. Some researchers are uncovering the complex interactions between the stomach, stomach microbes, and the brain. Other researchers are diving into how infants learn to communicate. And some researchers are creating robotic limbs that can not only restore movement, but also restore the sensation of touch for paralyzed or amputee patients. Skin can detect many different sensations, such as pressure or temperature; it rapidly sends this information to the brain, allowing us to perform many different tasks. The complex interaction between skin, muscle, and brain cells makes it difficult to restore sensation and movement in patients. But now, researchers are developing robotic limbs that can restore lost sensation. The robot contains contact sensors, and electrodes are placed in the patient’s skin just above the amputation site. The contact sensors are mapped with a computer algorithm to the electrodes, allowing the patient to sense the task the robot limb is performing. The results of the first trials seem extremely promising and it has been reported that when one patient touched an object with his robot figure, he had the sensation of brushing that object1.

1George, J. A., Kluger, D. T., Davis, T. S., Wendelken, S. M., Okorokova, E. V., He, Q., Duncan, C. C., Hutchinson, D. T., Thumser, Z. C., Beckler, D. T., Marasco, P. D., Bensmaia, S. J., & Clark, G. A. (2019). Biomimetic sensory feedback through peripheral nerve stimulation improves dexterous use of a bionic hand. Science robotics, 4(32), eaax2352.
https://doi.org/10.1126/scirobotics.aax2352

pageData.altText: An stylized illustration of many neurons.

pageData.text: The nervous system is made up of the central nervous system and peripheral nervous system. These systems work together to collect and interpret data from the body’s internal and external environment and control responses.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Nervous System

pageData.subTitle: Central Nervous System
pageData.text: The central nervous system (CNS) manages the body’s essential functions. Made up of the brain and spinal cord, the CNS receives sensory information and coordinates an appropriate response.

pageData.subTitle: Peripheral Nervous System
pageData.text: The peripheral nervous system (PNS) connects the CNS to the rest of the body. Nerves branch out from the brain and spinal cord, extending to the organs, muscles, and other parts of the body.

Neurons are highly specialized cells that transmit chemical and electrical information in the body. Neurons use short, branched extensions called dendrites to receive nerve impulses from surrounding cells. These messages then travel through the cell body to the axon, a threadlike structure. The impulse moves through the axon and is transmitted via chemical or electrical signals that pass through a synapse.
Neurotransmitters are chemicals that relay signals between neurons and bodily tissues. Neurotransmitters include adrenaline, dopamine, and endorphins.

The body is made up of organ systems, each with a specific role for maintaining life. Each organ system consists of a number of organs that operate collectively to carry out certain body functions. At every level of organization, whether at the cellular, tissue, organ, or organ system level, each structure always reflects its function and vice versa. This concept is known as the . In this activity, a mammalian brain will be examined and dissected to understand the relationship between structure (anatomy) and function (physiology).Organ systems do not operate independently, but rather are coordinated for the organism to survive. The interdependence of organ systems needed for —the dynamic equilibrium the body sustains when in good health—must be considered and understood. The brain is part of the nervous system, one of the two major control systems of the body, the other being the endocrine system. Together, the control systems regulate the workings of the other organ systems to maintain homeostasis.

Two major cell types account for most of the tissue in the nervous system: <button class='glossary-text'>neurons</button>, which receive and transmit electrochemical signals called <button class='glossary-text'>nerve impulses</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>glia</button> (also called glial cells or neuroglia), which provide support for the neurons. There are multiple types of neurons and glia. A typical neuron (Figure 1) has three major components: the <button class='glossary-text'>cell body</button>, which houses the nucleus and most of the organelles; an <button class='glossary-text'>axon</button>, which conveys impulses away from the cell body; and the <button class='glossary-text'>dendrites</button>, which convey impulses toward the cell body.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Drawing of a typical neuron showing the cell body with nucleus and dendrites, and axon with myelin sheath and axon terminal.

pageData.question: The structure of dendrites on a neuron is an example of the principle of complementarity of structure and function. Which of the following best describes the structure and function of dendrites?

options.text: Dendrites are highly branched; they convey impulses toward the neuron cell body.
Dendrites are long and thin; they convey impulses toward other neurons.
Dendrites are lipid sheaths; they insulate the impulse-conducting structures of a neuron.
Dendrites are large and fluid-filled; they house the organelles of the neuron.
Dendrites are bubble-like vesicles; they deliver chemical signals to other neurons.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Dendrites are highly branched structures that convey electrochemical signals, or nerve impulses, toward the cell body from other neurons.

pageData.question: Suppose a neuron has a genetic mutation that inhibits proper axon development. Which of the following best describes the effect of this mutation on the neuron?

options.text: Nerve impulses are not conveyed away from the cell body.
The cell body cannot receive nerve impulses.
The neuron lacks major internal organelles.
Nerve impulses are conducted to adjacent neurons more quickly.
The neuron has two nuclei instead of one.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Axons facilitate nerve impulse conduction from one neuron to the next. If the axon does not develop properly, nerve impulses cannot be conveyed away from the cell body.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The principle of complementarity of structure and function states that each structure always reflects its function and vice versa. This is true whether you are observing a cell, tissue, organ or organ system. For example, the organization of the bones in your chest (structure) provides a cage well suited for protecting soft vital organs, such as your heart and lungs (function). In the nervous system, at the cellular level, one of two major cell types is the neuron which receives and transmits nerve impulses. Observe the structure of a neuron as shown in Figure 1 and consider how its three major components each reflect its function: the cell body houses the nucleus and most of the organelles; dendrites convey nerve impulses toward the cell body; the axon conveys nerve impulses away from the cell body.

img.alt: Figure 1: Drawing of a typical neuron showing the cell body with nucleus and dendrites, and axon with myelin sheath and axon terminal.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The principle of complementarity of structure and function states that each structure always reflects its function and vice versa. This is true whether you are observing a cell, tissue, organ or organ system. For example, the organization of the bones in your chest (structure) provides a cage well suited for protecting soft vital organs, such as your heart and lungs (function). In the nervous system, at the cellular level, one of two major cell types is the neuron which receives and transmits nerve impulses. Observe the structure of a neuron as shown in Figure 1 and consider how its three major components each reflect its function: the cell body houses the nucleus and most of the organelles; dendrites convey nerve impulses toward the cell body; the axon conveys nerve impulses away from the cell body.

img.alt: Figure 1: Drawing of a typical neuron showing the cell body with nucleus and dendrites, and axon with myelin sheath and axon terminal.

pageData.text: The nervous system has two major divisions: the <button class='glossary-text'>central nervous system (CNS),</button> consisting of the brain and spinal cord, and the <button class='glossary-text'>peripheral nervous system (PNS),</button> a network of nerves and ganglia (clusters of neuronal cell bodies) located outside the CNS. The nervous system can also be described in terms of <button class='glossary-text'>gray matter</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>white matter</button>. Gray matter is made up mainly of neuronal cell bodies and <button class='glossary-text'>dendrites</button>, with some <button class='glossary-text'>axons</button>, together with <button class='glossary-text'>glia</button> and tiny blood vessels called capillaries. In preserved but unstained specimens, this type of nervous tissue appears gray. White matter appears white because the axons of which it is composed are sheathed in a fatty substance called <button class='glossary-text'>myelin</button>. This <button class='glossary-text'>myelin sheath</button> is produced by certain glia, and facilitates the rapid transmission of <button class='glossary-text'>nerve impulses</button> along the axons. Preserved, unstained myelinated axons have a shiny, white appearance. In the PNS, bundles of such axons are termed <button class='glossary-text'>nerves</button>, and in the CNS, they are known as <button class='glossary-text'>tracts</button>.

pageData.question: When performing your mammalian brain dissection, you would expect the nervous tissue containing mainly cell bodies, dendrites, glia and capillaries to be what color and why?

options.text: The tissue will be gray because it has few myelinated axons.
The tissue will be gray because glial cells decompose quickly even in preserved tissue.
The tissue will be white because it has many cell bodies, which produce fatty myelin sheaths.
The tissue will be white because it contains fewer cells to give the tissue pigmentation.
The tissue color depends on the age of the specimen.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Gray matter has few axons while white matter has many axons. Axons are covered in myelin sheaths, which are comprised of mostly fat. It is the myelin that gives axons a shiny, white appearance in preserved, unstained specimens.

pageData.question: Which of the following is present in white matter but is absent in gray matter?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The white color of white matter comes from the myelin that surrounds the axons in this type of nervous tissue. Gray matter has few myelinated neurons.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The central nervous system (CNS) can be described in terms of gray matter and white matter. The color difference is visible as darker and lighter tissue in preserved, unstained specimens (such as this preserved mammalian brain) and is due largely to the presence or absence of myelination of the axons in these tissues. Myelin is a fatty substance that covers the axons of some neurons like a sheath; it is produced by certain glia and facilitates the rapid transmission of nerve impulses along axons. When preserved, myelinated axons have a shiny, white appearance. Gray matter contains unmyelinated neurons, as well as glia and capillaries, while white matter contains neurons that are myelinated.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The central nervous system (CNS) can be described in terms of gray matter and white matter. The color difference is visible as darker and lighter tissue in preserved, unstained specimens (such as this preserved mammalian brain) and is due largely to the presence or absence of myelination of the axons in these tissues. Myelin is a fatty substance that covers the axons of some neurons like a sheath; it is produced by certain glia and facilitates the rapid transmission of nerve impulses along axons. When preserved, myelinated axons have a shiny, white appearance. Gray matter contains unmyelinated neurons, as well as glia and capillaries, while white matter contains neurons that are myelinated.

pageData.subTitle: Brain Structures and Their Functions
pageData.text: The brain is the most complex organ of the mammalian body. It has three major regions: the , , and . In addition, there is a region that coincides with the hindbrain and midbrain, known as the .

pageData.subTitle: THE HINDBRAIN
pageData.text: The hindbrain includes two parts of the brain stem, which links the brain and spinal cord; these are the , which is continuous with the spinal cord and regulates involuntary activities such as breathing, heartbeat, vomiting, coughing, and sneezing; and the bulb-shaped , an important relay center that helps regulate sleeping and breathing. The is also part of the hindbrain; cauliflower-like in appearance, it is of great importance in motor (movement) control. The , consists of , and the deeper, branching is known as the .

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the medulla, pons, and cerebellum labeled.

pageData.subTitle: THE MIDBRAIN
pageData.text: The midbrain is the third part of the brain stem, and serves to relay sensory and motor information between the spinal cord and the rest of the brain. The two of the midbrain help control the movement of the eyes, head, and neck in response to a stimulus such as a sudden loud noise or flash of light.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the midbrain labeled.

pageData.question: The brain stem, which links the brain and spinal cord, is considered part of which region(s) of the mammalian brain?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Two components of the brain stem are considered part of the hindbrain. The midbrain is the third part of the brain stem.

pageData.question: A patient is admitted to the hospital after suffering a traumatic brain injury. They are unresponsive to light and sound, as though in a deep sleep, but can breathe on their own. Which of the following regions of the patient’s brain is likely to be the least damaged?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The hindbrain consists of two parts of the brain stem, which regulates involuntary activities like breathing and heart rate. If the patient can breathe on their own, their hindbrain – especially their brain stem – is likely undamaged.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The hindbrain region refers to the structures at the base of the mammalian brain. This includes two parts of the brain stem: the medulla, which is continuous with the spinal cord and regulates involuntary activities (I.e., breathing, heartbeat, sneezing), and the pons, an important relay center that helps regulate sleeping and breathing. The cerebellum, which facilitates motor control, is also part of the hindbrain although not part of the brain stem. The midbrain region refers to the last part of the brain stem and serves to relay sensory and motor information between the spinal cord and the rest of the brain. The forebrain region refers to the structures of the brain above the mid- and hindbrain regions. This includes the hypothalamus, which secretes hormones and regulates homeostatic processes, the thalamus, which serves as a relay center for almost all sensory information, and the pineal body, which is an endocrine gland that helps regulate sleep-wake cycles and puberty.

img.alt: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the hindbrain, midbrain, and forebrain regions highlighted and labeled.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The hindbrain region refers to the structures at the base of the mammalian brain. This includes two parts of the brain stem: the medulla, which is continuous with the spinal cord and regulates involuntary activities (I.e., breathing, heartbeat, sneezing), and the pons, an important relay center that helps regulate sleeping and breathing. The cerebellum, which facilitates motor control, is also part of the hindbrain although not part of the brain stem. The midbrain region refers to the last part of the brain stem and serves to relay sensory and motor information between the spinal cord and the rest of the brain. The forebrain region refers to the structures of the brain above the mid- and hindbrain regions. This includes the hypothalamus, which secretes hormones and regulates homeostatic processes, the thalamus, which serves as a relay center for almost all sensory information, and the pineal body, which is an endocrine gland that helps regulate sleep-wake cycles and puberty.

img.alt: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the hindbrain, midbrain, and forebrain regions highlighted and labeled.

pageData.subTitle: THE FOREBRAIN
pageData.text: The consists of the , , , and .The hypothalamus is of particular interest because it contains specialized hormonesecreting , and is thus considered part of the endocrine system as well as the nervous system. The hypothalamus is crucial for regulating key processes that maintain .The thalamus is a very important “relay center” in the brain. All sensory information, with the exception of olfactory information, is relayed through the thalamus on its way to the cerebrum. Motor information from the and the of the cerebrum (discussed below) passes through the thalamus to the . In addition, the thalamus helps to regulate sleep and consciousness.The pineal body is a tiny endocrine gland located just to the posterior portion of the thalamus. It is sensitive to light, and secretes the hormone melatonin, which is important in the regulation of circadian rhythms (activities, such as sleeping and waking, that occur on an approximately 24-hour cycle), and the onset of sexual maturity.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the hypothalamus, thalamus, and pineal body labeled.

pageData.subTitle: THE FOREBRAIN (cont...)
pageData.text: The cerebrum is particularly prominent in mammals. Divided into right and left by a groove called the , the cerebrum organizes incoming sensory information, initiates voluntary motor activities, and is responsible for learning, memory, and judgment. The has a distinctive wrinkled appearance. The cerebral cortex consists of , and the wrinkles increase the surface area of the cortex. The crests of the wrinkles are called (singular, gyrus) and the shallow grooves are called (singular, sulcus). lie deep to the gray matter of the cerebral cortex. The most prominent of these is the that connects the cerebral hemispheres.Embedded in the white matter are collections of gray matter known as the (or, in some older texts, the basal ganglia). The basal nuclei play important roles in voluntary and habitual movements, and in learning.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the cerebrum and corpus callosum labeled.

pageData.subTitle: THE FOREBRAIN (cont...)
pageData.text: The can be structurally and functionally divided into regions referred to as lobes. The is responsible for cognitive processes such as planning, reasoning, judgement, and the control of emotional and sexual drives. The integrates sensory information (for example, from receptors in the skin) and functions in spatial perception, i.e., the ability to assess the shape, size, orientation, and motion of objects. The functions in auditory perception (including language) and longterm memory. The receives and processes visual information.The human brain contains four ventricles. The are located in the cerebrum, separated by the . The is located between the two halves of the , and the is located between the and the .

pageData.altText: Figure 6: The human brain with the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital lobes highlighted and labeled.

pageData.question: While running for the ball, two athletes crash into one another. One athlete hits the back of their head on the ground and is taken to the sidelines. As they talk to the team doctor, they describe that upon hitting their head they saw bright flashes of light. Which of the following best explains the relationship between the athlete’s injury and the flashes they saw?

options.text: The back of the head is where the occipital lobe of the mammalian brain is located.
The back of the head is where the mammalian brain stem is located.
The back of the head is where the right hemisphere of the cerebrum is located.
The back of the head is where the temporal lobe of the mammalian brain is located.
The back of the head is where the cerebral cortex of the mammalian forebrain is located.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The occipital lobe, which receives and processes visual information, is located at the back (anterior side) of the mammalian brain. Hitting this part of their head caused the athlete to perceive flashes of light in their field of vision that weren’t there.

pageData.question: A young woman has just returned home after recovering from a brain injury. Despite a scar on her forehead, she is perfectly healthy; however, the woman’s friends and colleagues describe her as uncharacteristically irritable and rash after the accident. Which of the following best describes the nature of the woman’s injury?

options.text: The woman injured part of her frontal lobe.
The woman’s temporal lobes were removed as part of the surgery.
The woman’s corpus callosum was severed.
The woman injured her brain stem.
The woman’s injury caused more basal nuclei to develop in her brain.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The frontal lobe is responsible for cognitive processes, such as judgment, reasoning and control of emotional and sexual drives. It is likely that the personality changes described by her close associates were a result of damage to a portion of the woman’s frontal lobe.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The prominent cerebrum of the mammalian forebrain can be organized in several different ways. It can be viewed as right and left halves, or hemispheres, divided by a deep groove called the medial longitudinal fissure. These hemispheres are connected by a large tract of white matter called the corpus callosum. The cerebrum can also be viewed as different regions or lobes. The frontal lobe facilitates cognitive processes like reasoning and emotion. The parietal lobe processes sensory and spatial information. The temporal lobe facilitates language processing and long-term memory. The occipital lobe receives and processes visual information.

img.alt: Figure 6: The human brain with the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital lobes highlighted and labeled.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The prominent cerebrum of the mammalian forebrain can be organized in several different ways. It can be viewed as right and left halves, or hemispheres, divided by a deep groove called the medial longitudinal fissure. These hemispheres are connected by a large tract of white matter called the corpus callosum. The cerebrum can also be viewed as different regions or lobes. The frontal lobe facilitates cognitive processes like reasoning and emotion. The parietal lobe processes sensory and spatial information. The temporal lobe facilitates language processing and long-term memory. The occipital lobe receives and processes visual information.

img.alt: Figure 6: The human brain with the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital lobes highlighted and labeled.

pageData.subTitle: MENINGES
pageData.text: The CNS is protected from injury in several ways. The bones of the cranium and spine provide support and resistance to impact. A series of three connective tissue layers called lie to these protective bones but external to the nervous tissue. The (also known simply as the dura) is the outermost of the meninges; the is a delicate layer that adheres closely to the surface of the CNS; and located between them is the , which has a texture similar to that of a spider web.

pageData.subTitle: VENTRICLES
pageData.text: The CNS is essentially a hollow tube, having internal spaces filled with clear, colorless . The brain contains four interconnected, CSF-filled ventricles. The right and left ventricles are located in the cerebrum, separated by the . The is located between the right and left halves of the ; it contains a specialized epithelium called the that produces the CSF. The is located between the and the .

CSF circulates through the central canal of the spinal cord and the four ventricles of the brain, and within the , which lies between the pia mater and the arachnoid. CSF is a vital part of CNS circulation, and, especially within the subarachnoid space, helps to cushion the CNS and serve as a “shock absorber.”

pageData.subTitle: SENSORY STRUCTURES
pageData.text: related to vision and the sense of smell (olfaction) are prominently visible on the external, aspect of the brain.The retinas of the eyes are mainly composed of nervous tissue, and are considered part of the brain. Retinal give rise to the originating in each eye. The pair of optic come together to form an X-shaped structure, the (or optic chiasma), located near the base of the brain near the . This is where many nerve fibers decussate, or crisscross, before continuing via the to the thalamus. Decussation of nerve fibers carrying visual information is essential for binocular vision, i.e., the formation of a single, continuous image using input from both eyes.The lie anterior to the optic chiasm. They are quite prominent in mammals with a keen sense of smell, and even humans, with our relatively weak olfactory abilities, possess olfactory bulbs. Olfactory information is not relayed through the thalamus; rather, it passes to a number of brain areas, including those devoted to memory and emotion, as well as sensory perception.

Anatomists and health care providers use a very specific terminology that enables them to precisely communicate their work. Directional anatomical terms are used for describing the relative positions of different body structures or to provide instructions for incisions. Directional anatomical terms (Table 1 and Figure 7) are used in this and most other dissection guides to describe the relative positions of body structures. Therefore, learning these terms is essential for the understanding and study of anatomy.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Drawings of the midsagittal, frontal, and transverse anatomical planes of a quadruped, represented by a cat, and a biped, represented by a human.

tableData.text: Above, over; synonymous with dorsal in brain dissection, especially for a quadruped
Below, under; synonymous with ventral in brain dissection, especially for a quadruped
Away from the midline; to the side
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.text: Note: All mammalian brains are similar in structure and function. However, there is one distinct difference between the brain stem and spinal cord of a biped, such as a human, and those of a quadruped, such as a sheep or cat. A biped is a vertical animal that walks on two legs; thus, the spinal cord and brain stem are perpendicular to the ground. The spinal cord and brain stem of a quadruped are parallel to the ground.

pageData.question: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) circulates through the spinal cord, the subarachnoid space, and what other structure(s)?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: CSF circulates through the four interconnected ventricles of the mammalian brain.

pageData.question: Which of the following structures is responsible for production of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The choroid plexus produces CSF, which circulates through the spinal cord, the subarachnoid space, and the ventricles of the brain.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is important to the circulation of nutrients and waste, as well shock absorption, in the central nervous system (CNS). CSF is produced by the choroid plexus, the specialized epithelium located between the right and left halves of the thalamus. This area is a hollow space in the brain and is also known as one of the brain’s four ventricles: there are two lateral ventricles in the cerebrum, separated by the septum pellucidum, and another ventricle located between the cerebellum and the brain stem. These ventricles are filled with CSF, along with the central canal of the spinal cord and the subarachnoid space, which lies between the pia mater and the arachnoid.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is important to the circulation of nutrients and waste, as well shock absorption, in the central nervous system (CNS). CSF is produced by the choroid plexus, the specialized epithelium located between the right and left halves of the thalamus. This area is a hollow space in the brain and is also known as one of the brain’s four ventricles: there are two lateral ventricles in the cerebrum, separated by the septum pellucidum, and another ventricle located between the cerebellum and the brain stem. These ventricles are filled with CSF, along with the central canal of the spinal cord and the subarachnoid space, which lies between the pia mater and the arachnoid.

pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by setting up the work area and dissection the tools. 
In Activity 1, you will locate and identify external structures of the intact specimen. Then, divide the specimen longitudinally. Next, locate and identify the internal structures of the specimen. You will then create a cross section of the frontal lobe. Next Identify the cerebral gray matter versus white matter.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: A replacement Carolina’s Perfect Solution® Mammalian Brain (item number 580179) or a replacement Dissecting Set (item number 580021) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
This investigation requires safety glasses, disposable gloves, and a lab apron.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE); safety glasses, gloves, and lab aprons must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets (SDS) before beginning the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:

text: Clean the counter or workspace thoroughly before and after the dissection using isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant).

pageData.altText: flammable symbol
pageData.text: Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as disinfectant.

text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
Only perform the dissection on the dissecting tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
Spread the absorbent pad blue-side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.
In general, scissors are used more frequently than the scalpel, especially when care must be taken not to cut too deeply into the specimen.
Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal:

pageData.text:
-  Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
 -  Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
 -  Always use a sharp blade.
 -  Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
 -  Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
 -  Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.subTitle: Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>
pageData.text: Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution® have found that it is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® specimens does not require specialized ventilation. Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well-ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.

pageData.altText: warning symbol
pageData.text: Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and eyes. Do not ingest specimen, especially if you are or may become pregnant.

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, you may choose to place it in the plastic storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the opening with a rubber band, tape, or a binder clip. After closing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Anatomy relates to physiology as structure relates to which of the following?
Which of the following describes one of the main types of nervous tissue and its function?

assestmentData.pageTitle: Drag and Drop Knowledge Check Question
assestmentData.question: Label the parts of the nerve cell.
Gray matter and white matter in the brain differ in their structure and function. Which of the following best describes these differences?

options.text: White matter has myelinated neurons and rapidly transmits nerve impulses.
Gray matter has enlarged cell bodies and supports the brain with nutrients.
White matter is made up of glia and secretes hormones.
Gray matter is made of epithelial tissue and produces cerebrospinal fluid.
Gray matter is only found in the brain stem and facilitates involuntary processes.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the ventricles of the brain?

options.text: They are hollow spaces filled with cerebrospinal fluid.
They are regions for different types of cognitive function.
They are the parts of the brain stem that connect the brain to the spinal cord.
They are transparent membranes that surround the brain.

assestmentData.question: Jonah hopes to attend a prestigious art school on a ballet scholarship. Which of the following structures of the brain is most critical to Jonah’s ability to control his movements as he dances?
Which of the following structures of the brain secretes the hormone responsible for maintaining circadian rhythms?
Which of the following structures separates the left and right cerebral hemispheres of the brain?
Which of the following scenarios describes inappropriate handling of a scalpel?

options.text: Britney places her holding hand inferior to the movement of her scalpel.
Nora disposes of her scalpel after noticing the blade is bent.
Susan uses consistent pressure as she makes a small incision.
Esther makes an incision by moving the scalpel down toward the tray.
Marta trades the scalpel for scissors when she encounters thick cartilage mid-incision.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a safety concern of the preservation fluid used to preserve the mammalian brain provided for this investigation?

options.text: It can cause mild skin irritation if proper PPE is not worn.
It gives off toxic fumes and must be used in a well-ventilated area.
It is corrosive and must be stored in its original container.
It cannot be disposed of in the household trash.
If you are or may become pregnant, do not open the specimen.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Review the dissection instructions and the glossary at the end of this investigation.
Print out the dissection procedure to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.
Clean the work area. Put on your PPE: safety glasses, gloves, and lab apron, and keep them on during the dissection and cleanup.
Lay the pad on the work area with the white, absorbent side facing up.
Lay the scalpel, forceps, and probe from the dissecting set on the pad.
Inspect the scalpel. Do not use the scalpel if it is bent, nicked, or damaged.
Place the dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Position the dissecting mat so it is easily viewed.

You will start Activity 1 by examining the external structures of the intact mammalian brain. Then, you will divide the preserved brain specimen into equal left and right halves and examine the internal structures. You will conclude by making a cross section of the <button class='glossary-text'>frontal lobe</button> of one of the specimen halves.

pages.pageTitle:
A
  Dissection of the Mammalian Brain (3 steps)
pages.title:
A
  Dissection of the Mammalian Brain (3 steps)

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text:
Begin by studying the external features of the intact mammalian brain. Using the dissecting mat as a guide, locate and identify the following structures. Numbers in parentheses correspond to numbered structures on the mat. In the following steps you are asked to identify and photograph a number of structures. Each photograph may have multiple structures shown. Take notes to keep track of which structures are presented in each picture.
  1. Cerebrum (1): (19) and (20); left (8) and right (10) ; (9); (4), (5), (6), and (7)
  2. (2)
  3. (11): (18), (13), and (12)
  4. Spinal cord (3)
  5. (15), (16), and (14)
  6. (17)

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text:
Position the brain side up (top side up), and use the scalpel to cut the entire brain longitudinally into equal right and left halves, as shown on the back of the dissecting mat. Insert the scalpel into the most frontal part of the longitudinal fissure, and make your cut by moving the scalpel slowly and evenly toward the posterior. Using the dissecting mat as a guide, locate and identify the following:
  1. Cerebrum (1): left (8) and right (10) hemispheres
  2. Cerebellum (2) and (25)
  3. (31)
  4. Brain stem (11): midbrain (18) with (26), pons (13), and medulla (12)
  5. (30)
  6. (32)
  7. Spinal cord (3)
  8. (29)
  9. Ventricles: left ventricle (23), right lateral ventricle (opposite the left), with (21); (22), (24)

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Using the scalpel, make a cross section of a <button class='glossary-text'>frontal lobe</button> of the cerebrum, as shown on the back of the dissecting mat. Distinguish between cerebral <button class='glossary-text'>white matter</button> (33) and <button class='glossary-text'>gray matter</button> (34).
Dispose of any excess fluids down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about 30 seconds to dilute the fluids.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: Place the specimen in its storage bag and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimen, put the bag into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>
Rinse and carefully air dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your equipment kit.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>

Sanitize the workspace with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels. If this is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.content: Figure 1. The parts of a neuron
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Drawing of a typical neuron showing the cell body with nucleus and dendrites, and axon with myelin sheath and axon terminal.

pageData.content: Figure 2. The parts of the hindbrain
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the medulla, pons, and cerebellum labeled.
Figure 3: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the midbrain labeled.

pageData.content: Figure 4. The hypothalamus, thalamus, and pineal body
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the hypothalamus, thalamus, and pineal body labeled.

pageData.content: Figure 5. The cerebrum and corpus callosum
pageData.altText: Figure 5: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the cerebrum and corpus callosum labeled.

pageData.content: Figure 6. The lobes of the brain
pageData.altText: Figure 6: The human brain with the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital lobes highlighted and labeled.

tableData.text: Above, over; synonymous with dorsal in brain dissection, especially for a quadruped
Below, under; synonymous with ventral in brain dissection, especially for a quadruped
Away from the midline; to the side
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.content: Figure 7. Anatomical planes of a quadruped and biped
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Drawings of the midsagittal, frontal, and transverse anatomical planes of a quadruped, represented by a cat, and a biped, represented by a human.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will start by setting up the work area and dissection the tools. 
In Activity 1, you will locate and identify external structures of the intact specimen. Then, divide the specimen longitudinally. Next, locate and identify the internal structures of the specimen. You will then create a cross section of the frontal lobe. Next Identify the cerebral gray matter versus white matter.

data.title: Arachnoid
data.content: Located between dura and pia mater

data.title: Arbor vitae
data.content: Deep branching white matter

data.title: Axon
data.content: Conveys impulses away from the cell body

data.title: Basal nuclei
data.content: Collections of gray matter embedded in the white matter

data.title: Brain stem
data.content: Region that coincides with the hindbrain and midbrain

data.title: Caudal
data.content: Toward the tail; synonymous with inferior in bipeds

data.title: Cell body
data.content: Houses the nucleus and most of the organelles (soma)

data.title: Central nervous system (CNS)
data.content: The brain and spinal cord

data.title: Cerebellar cortex
data.content: Consists of gray matter, and the deeper, branching white matter

data.title: Cerebellum
data.content: Part of the hindbrain; cauliflower-like in appearance, it is of great importance in motor (movement) control

data.title: Cerebral cortex
data.content: Consists of gray matter, and the wrinkles increase the surface area of the cortex

data.title: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
data.content: Clear, colorless fluid that fills the CNS

data.title: Choroid plexus
data.content: Specialized epithelium that produces the CSF

data.title: Corpus callosum
data.content: Connects the cerebral hemispheres

data.title: Cranial
data.content: Toward the head; synonymous with superior in bipeds

data.title: Deep
data.content: Below the surface of the body or a structure; internal

data.title: Dendrite
data.content: Convey impulses toward the cell body

data.title: Dorsal
data.content: Toward the back of the body; synonymous with superior in quadrupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with posterior in describing the biped body other than the head

data.title: Dura mater (dura)
data.content: The outermost of the meninges, CNS

data.title: Forebrain
data.content: Consists of the hypothalamus, thalamus, pineal body, and cerebrum

data.title: Fourth ventricle
data.content: Located between the cerebellum and the brain stem

data.title: Frontal lobe
data.content: Responsible for cognitive processes such as planning, reasoning, judgement, and the control of emotional and sexual drives

data.title: Frontal plane
data.content: Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

data.title: Glia
data.content: Provide support for the neurons (called glial cells or neuroglia)

data.title: Gray matter
data.content: The darker tissue of the brain and spinal cord, consisting mainly of made up mainly of neuronal cell bodies; dendrites; and short, unmyelinated axons, together with glia and tiny blood vessels

data.title: Gyrus (plural, gyri)
data.content: The wrinkles in the cerebral cortex

data.title: Hemisphere
data.content: Half of a spherical or roughly spherical structure or organ

data.title: Hindbrain
data.content: Includes two parts of the brain stem, which links the brain and spinal cord

data.title: Homeostasis
data.content: Is a self-regulating process by which biological systems maintain stability while adjusting to environmental changes

data.title: Hypothalamus
data.content: Contains specialized hormone-secreting neurons, and is thus considered part of the endocrine system as well as the nervous system

data.title: Inferior
data.content: Away from the head end of the biped body, or toward the lower part of a structure; below

data.title: Lateral
data.content: Away from the midline of the body; to the side

data.title: Medial
data.content: Toward the midline

data.title: Medial longitudinal fissure
data.content: A deep groove that divides the brain into right and left hemispheres

data.title: Medulla
data.content: Inner region

data.title: Meninges
data.content: A series of three connective tissue layers, CNS

data.title: Midbrain
data.content: Part of the brain stem, and serves to relay sensory and motor information between the spinal cord and the rest of the brain

data.title: Midsagittal plane
data.content: Divides the body into equal left and right halves; often referred to as the midline or median plane

data.title: Myelin
data.content: A fatty substance

data.title: Myelin sheath
data.content: An insulating layer that forms around nerves

data.title: Nerve
data.content: Bundle of myelinated axons that transmits impulses of sensation to the brain or spinal cord, and impulses from these to the muscles and organs

data.title: Nerve impulse
data.content: Electrochemical signal

data.title: Neuron
data.content: Receive and transmit electrochemical signals (nerve impulses)

data.title: Node of Ranvier
data.content: The gaps between Myelin on an axon which allow for increased conduction speed of nerve impulses

data.title: Occipital lobe
data.content: Receives and processes visual information

data.title: Olfactory bulb
data.content: A rounded mass of tissue that contains several types of nerve cells that are involved in the sense of smell, lies under the frontal lobe of the brain

data.title: Optic chiasm
data.content: Located near the base of the brain near the hypothalamus

data.title: Optic nerve
data.content: Convergence of nerve fibers in the optic disk gives rise to the optic nerve, which leads to the brain

data.title: Optic tract
data.content: Extension of the optic nerve located in the brain

data.title: Parietal lobe
data.content: Integrates sensory information (for example, from receptors in the skin) and functions in spatial perception, i.e., the ability to assess the shape, size, orientation, and motion of objects

data.title: Peripheral nervous system (PNS)
data.content: A network of nerves that extend throughout the body

data.title: Pia mater
data.content: A delicate layer that adheres closely to the surface of the CNS

data.title: Pineal body
data.content: A tiny endocrine gland located just inferior to the posterior portion of the thalamus

data.title: Pon
data.content: An important relay center that helps regulate sleeping and breathing

data.title: Principle of complementarity of structure and function
data.content: Each anatomical structure always reflects its function and vice versa

data.title: Right and left lateral ventricles
data.content: Located in the cerebrum

data.title: Rostral
data.content: Toward the nose or mouth

data.title: Sagittal plane
data.content: Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions

data.title: Schwann Cell
data.content: A glial cell which produces myelin

data.title: Sensory structures
data.content: Related to vision and the sense of smell (olfaction) are prominently visible on the external, inferior aspect of the brain

data.title: Septum pellucidum
data.content: Separates the right and left lateral ventricles

data.title: Subarachnoid space
data.content: Lies between the pia mater and the arachnoid

data.title: Sulcus (plural, sulci)
data.content: Shallow grooves in the cerebral cortex

data.title: Superficial
data.content: Toward or along the surface of the body or a structure; external

data.title: Superior
data.content: Toward the head end of the biped body, or the upper part of a structure; above

data.title: Superior colliculi
data.content: Part of the midbrain help control the movement of the eyes, head, and neck in response to a stimulus such as a sudden loud noise or flash of light

data.title: Temporal lobe
data.content: Functions in auditory perception (including language) and long-term memory

data.title: Thalamus
data.content: A very important “relay center” in the brain. All sensory information, with the exception of olfactory information, is relayed through the thalamus on its way to the cerebrum

data.title: Third ventricle
data.content: Located between the two halves of the thalamus

data.title: Tract
data.content: A bundle of fibers in the nervous system, mostly white matter

data.title: Transverse plane
data.content: Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections

data.title: Ventral
data.content: Toward the belly or abdomen of the body; synonymous with inferior in quadrupeds, or in bipeds when referring to the head

data.title: White matter
data.content: Appears white because the axons are sheathed in a fatty substance, myelin sheath
